Graphical abstract A series of Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 (15Ni-XSr/AZ) xerogel catalysts with different strontium content (X, wt%) were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol-gel method followed by a co-impregnation method. Un-promoted Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 (15Ni/AZ) xerogel catalyst was also prepared according to the similar methods for comparison. Surface area of the catalysts decreased with increasing strontium content. Excess amount of impregnated strontium on the catalyst led to weakened metal-support interaction, inducing formation of large nickel particles in the reduced catalysts with high Sr loading. Introduction of strontium promoter reduced acidity of the catalysts, leading to a more favorable reaction pathway during the ethanol steam reforming reaction. Promotion with strontium generally had a positive effect on the catalytic activity due to enhanced nickel dispersion and suppressed acidity. Nickel surface area and ethanol adsorption capacity exhibited volcano-shaped trends with respect to strontium content. Hydrogen yield increased with increasing nickel surface area and with increasing ethanol adsorption capacity of the catalyst. Among the catalysts tested, 15Ni-6Sr/AZ, which retained the highest nickel surface area and the largest ethanol adsorption capacity, showed the highest hydrogen yield in the steam reforming of ethanol. It was concluded that an optimal amount of strontium promoter was required to achieve the best catalytic performance. Keywords Hydrogen production Steam reforming of ethanol Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst Strontium promoter Nickel surface area 1 Introduction Restricted supplies of conventional fossil fuel sources and associated environmental problems have triggered extensive researches on the development of alternative energy sources [1,2]. Among various sustainable energy sources, hydrogen is a promising candidate with characteristics of ampleness, high efficiency, renewability, and broad usage [3,4]. In this respect, methods for efficient and consistent production of hydrogen have attracted much attention, where steam reforming of methane is one of the major techniques employed for large-scale hydrogen production [5]. Apart from methane, ethanol is also a promising source for steam reforming process due to its eco-friendly trait, ease of storage and transportation, and feasibility of biomass-based production [6]. Ethanol steam reforming reaction consists of various possible reaction pathways, where in an ideal case, one ethanol molecule goes through steam reforming reaction with three molecules of water to yield six molecules of hydrogen and no by-products other than carbon dioxide (Eq. (1)) [7]. Other intermediates such as acetaldehyde, methane, ethylene, carbon monoxide can be formed via various reaction pathways such as dehydrogenation (Eq. (2)), decomposition (Eq. (3)), dehydration (Eq. (4)), Boudouard reaction (Eq. (5)), and water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (6)) [8]. Coking is the main drawback in the catalytic ethanol steam reforming systems, which is formed from multiple side reactions such as methane decomposition (Eq. (7)), CO de-oxygenation (Eq. (8)), and ethylene polymerization [9]. (1) C2H5OH+3H2O→2CO2 +6H2 (ΔH°298K =+174kJ/mol) (2) C2H5OH→CH3CHO+H2 (ΔH°298K =+68kJ/mol) (3) C2H5OH→CH4 +CO+H2 (ΔH°298K =+49kJ/mol) (4) C2H5OH→C2H4 +H2O (ΔH°298K =+45kJ/mol) (5) 2CO→CO2 +C (ΔH°298K =−172kJ/mol) (6) CO+H2O→CO2 +H2 (ΔH°298K =−41kJ/mol) (7) CH4 →C+2H2 (8) CO+H2 →C+H2O Many researches dealing with diverse catalytic systems for ethanol steam reforming have been made in order to facilitate reaction pathways, leading to enhanced hydrogen yield and suppressed side reactions [10–13]. Noble metal such as Rh is reported to exhibit a remarkable performance in the ethanol steam reforming, but its high price causes hardship upon industrial application [14]. In case of non-noble transition metal-based catalytic systems, nickel catalyst supported on alumina (Ni/Al2O3) has been widely studied and applied because nickel is cheap and nickel shows a favorable activity in CC bond cleavage [15–17]. Considering that Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is prone to suffer from deactivation which generally results from coke formation on acidic sites of alumina support, various modifications have been made with an aim to enhance catalytic activity and stability [18]. Introduction of lanthanum species to alumina support resulted in enhanced catalytic stability, because La2O3 on the catalyst surface interacted with surface oxygen to remove coke [19]. Zirconium was also studied in the modification of alumina support. For example, Ni-Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst showed more stable and efficient hydrogen yield than Ni-Al2O3 catalyst due to the decrease of support acidity [20]. It was also revealed that steam adsorption capacity of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was improved with the introduction of zirconia [21]. Alkaline earth metals, especially magnesium and calcium, have been utilized as catalyst components in the steam reforming reactions because of their basic nature [22]. Steam reforming catalyst with magnesium-modified alumina support is reported to show high degree of H2O dissociation on the support, leading to enhanced catalytic activity [23]. Copper-nickel bimetallic catalyst showed high selectivity for hydrogen and stable catalytic performance when promoted with magnesium and calcium [24]. Thus, promotion of various steam reforming catalysts with magnesium and calcium had multifarious benefits. However, there are only a few works concerning the effect of strontium promotion [25]. In this respect, a study dealing with the effect of strontium promotion on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activities of Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst in the steam reforming of ethanol would be worthwhile. In this work, a series of Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 (15Ni-XSr/AZ) xerogel catalysts with different strontium content (X, wt%) were prepared. Un-promoted Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 (15Ni/AZ) xerogel catalyst was also prepared for comparison. The effect of Sr content on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activities of Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalysts in the steam reforming of ethanol was investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Supported nickel catalysts promoted with strontium were prepared by co-impregnating nickel and strontium precursors on Al2O3-ZrO2 (denoted as AZ) xerogel support. AZ support was prepared in advance by a single step epoxide-driven sol-gel method. 0.74g of zirconium precursor (zirconium oxynitrate hydrate, Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) was initially dissolved in 30ml of ethanol. 6g of aluminum precursor (aluminum nitrate nonahydrate, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) and 3ml of hydrochloric acid (hydrochloric acid, Samchun, 36%) were subsequently added into the solution containing zirconium precursor. After vigorous stirring at room temperature, a translucent homogeneous solution was obtained. Upon addition of 15ml of propylene oxide (Samchun, 99%) as a gelation agent into the homogeneous solution, an opaque alumina-zirconia composite gel was formed within a few minutes. The resultant gel was aged for 2 days, dried at 80°C for 5 days, and calcined at 550°C for 5h to yield alumina-zirconia (AZ) xerogel support. A known amount of nickel precursor (nickel nitrate hexahydrate, Sigma-Aldrich, 97%) and an appropriate amount of strontium precursor (strontium nitrate, Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) were dissolved in 20ml of deionized water. AZ support was introduced into the aqueous solution containing nickel and strontium precursors for co-impregnation at 85°C. After impregnation, the resulting powder was dried at 80°C for 12h, and it was calcined at 550°C for 5h to yield Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst. The prepared catalysts were denoted as 15Ni-XSr/AZ (X=2, 4, 6, 8, and 10), where X represented the amount of strontium loading (wt%). Un-promoted Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 (denoted as 15Ni/AZ) catalyst was also prepared according to the similar methods mentioned above. Nickel loading was fixed at 15wt% in all the catalysts. 2.2 Characterization Textural properties of calcined catalysts were investigated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments using a BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan) device. Prior to the measurement, each sample was degassed at 150°C for 3h with a vacuum pump to remove surface impurities. BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method was applied to the isotherm plots when calculating specific surface areas of the catalysts. To determine the amount of nickel and strontium loadings on AZ support, ICP-AES (inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy) analyses were carried out with an ICPS-100IV (Shimadzu) device. For ICP-AES analysis, each sample was pretreated by dissolving trace amount of catalyst in an acidic mixed solution of hydrochloric acid and nitric acid. XRD (X-ray diffraction) analyses were carried out for the observation of crystalline structures using a D-Max2500-PC (Rigaku) device. Operating conditions during the XRD analyses were kept at 50kV and 100mA under Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.541Å). TPR (temperature-programmed reduction) measurements were conducted to evaluate metal-support interaction of the catalysts. 100mg of each calcined catalyst was charged into a quartz reactor. The catalyst sample was then reduced by elevating furnace temperature from room temperature to 1000°C at a rate of 10°C/min under a mixed flow of hydrogen (2ml/min) and nitrogen (20ml/min). NH3-TPD (temperature-programmed desorption) analyses were carried out with a BELCAT-B instrument (BEL Japan) to determine acid property of the catalysts. For NH3-TPD analysis, 20mg of each sample was charged into a quartz reactor, and it was reduced at 700°C for 2h under a 5% hydrogen/argon flow (50ml/min). After cooling down the reactor to 50°C, ammonia adsorption was done with a 5% ammonia/helium flow (50ml/min) for 1h. Physisorbed ammonia was removed by purging the reactor under a helium flow (50ml/min) at 100°C for 1h. Furnace temperature was elevated from 50°C to 800°C at a rate of 5°C/min under a helium flow (30ml/min). The amount of ammonia desorbed was detected with a TCD (thermal conductivity detector). Morphologies and particle size distributions of reduced catalysts were examined by TEM (transmission electron microscopy) analyses (JEM-2000EXII, Jeol). To measure nickel surface area of reduced catalysts, H2-TPD analyses were conducted with a BELCAT-B instrument (BEL Japan). For H2-TPD analysis, 50mg of each catalyst was reduced under a 5% hydrogen/argon flow (50ml/min) at 700°C for 2h after being charged into a quartz reactor. Hydrogen was adsorbed by treating the sample with a 5% hydrogen/argon flow (50ml/min) at 50°C for 30min until the catalyst surface was saturated with hydrogen molecules. The reactor was then purged under an argon flow (50ml/min) at 100°C for 1h to remove physisorbed hydrogen. The amount of hydrogen desorbed was detected using a TCD by increasing furnace temperature from 50°C to 1000°C at a rate of 5°C/min under an argon flow (30ml/min). To calculate nickel surface area from H2-TPD profiles, adsorption stoichiometry of H/Ni was assumed as 1 and cross-sectional area of a single nickel atom was taken as 6.49×10−20 m2. For EtOH-TPD experiment, 100mg of each catalyst was charged into a quartz reactor. Under a mixed flow of hydrogen (3ml/min) and helium (30ml/min), the sample was reduced at 700°C for 2h. The reactor was cooled down to room temperature under a 5ml/min of helium flow. Ethanol was adsorbed by pulsing 15ml of vaporized ethanol into the reactor for 10 times until the catalyst surface was saturated with ethanol under a helium flow (5ml/min). The reactor was then evacuated at 100°C for 1h under a flow of helium (15ml/min) to remove physisorbed ethanol. Furnace temperature was elevated from room temperature to 700°C at a rate of 5°C/min under a helium flow (10ml/min). The desorbed species were detected with a GC–MSD (6890N GC-5975MSD, Agilent) apparatus. The desorbed species were characterized according to m/z values; 16, 28, 29, 31, and 44 for CH4, CO, CH3CHO, C2H5OH, and CO2, respectively. 2.3 Steam reforming of ethanol The catalytic activity of 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ (X=2, 4, 6, 8, and 10) catalysts in the ethanol steam reforming was evaluated in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor at 450°C for 1000min under atmospheric pressure. 100mg of each catalyst was reduced at 700°C for 2h prior to the reaction under a flow of hydrogen (3ml/min) diluted with nitrogen (30ml/min). During the reforming reaction, nitrogen carrier gas (30ml/min) was flowed into the apparatus with continuous injection of ethanol-deionized water liquid mixture (1ml/h) by a syringe pump (US/KDS-101, KDScientific). The molar ratio of steam to ethanol in the reactant was fixed at 6. Inlet line of the reactor was preheated at 200°C in order to maintain the reactant mixture at a vapor phase. Total feed rate with respect to catalyst weight was maintained at 28,280ml/(hgcat). The composition of outlet gas was analyzed with a TCD equipped on an on-line gas chromatograph (ACME 6000, Younglin). Products were separated using Porapak N and Molecular Sieve 5A columns. Hydrogen yield, ethanol conversion, and selectivity for carbon-containing products were calculated with the following equations. In Eq. (11), ni represents the stoichiometric factor of carbon-containing species. All the catalysts exhibited H2 type hysteresis loops, indicating the formation of mesoporous structure consisting of ‘ink-bottle’ shaped pores of non-uniform size and shape [26]. This feature originates from preliminarily prepared AZ xerogel support, because pore shrinkage occurring during the conventional xerogel drying process leads to different sizes of opening and body of mesopores [27]. Pore size distributions of the samples are also shown in Fig. 1(b). All the samples showed that majority of pores formed during the catalyst preparation step fit into the mesoporous range (5–15nm), indicating that mesoporous 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts were successfully prepared in this work. Detailed physicochemical properties of calcined catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . All the calcined samples showed high surface area (>164m2/g), large pore volume (>0.24cm3/g), and large pore diameter (>5.9nm). Actual amounts of nickel and strontium loaded on AZ support were in good agreement with the designed values. It was also observed that un-promoted 15Ni/AZ catalyst retained the highest surface area (229m2/g) and the largest pore volume (0.42cm3/g). With increasing the amount of co-impregnated strontium, surface area and pore volume of the catalysts decreased. 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalyst showed the smallest surface area (164m2/g) and pore volume (0.24cm3/g). Suppressed textural properties of promoted catalysts may be due to partial blockage and obstruction of support mesopores caused by additionally impregnated strontium species with relatively large atomic radius [28,29]. 3.2 XRD and TPR analyses of calcined catalysts In Fig. 2 , XRD patterns of calcined 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts are shown. Diffraction peaks corresponding to NiO phase were detected in all the catalysts. This implies that nickel species existed as NiO on alumina-zirconia after impregnation, rather than being incorporated into the support as NiAl2O4. In addition, no diffraction peaks related to alumina-zirconia support were observed. This indicates that alumina and zirconia formed a mixed metal oxide, where crystalline growth of each individual metal oxide structure was suppressed to remain as an amorphous phase [30]. As for the promoter, diffraction peaks indicating the formation of mixed oxide species (SrNiO3) were detected in the 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalysts with high strontium loading. It is expected that the substantial amount of strontium existing on these catalysts led to the formation of strontium nickel oxide during the catalyst preparation step. The peak was more pronounced in the 15Ni-10Sr/AZ than in the 15Ni-8Sr/AZ, while the other catalyst samples did not show strontium-related peak due to relatively small amount of strontium loading. Fig. 3 . shows the TPR profiles of calcined 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts. The catalysts showed a major reduction band at around 700°C. This peak was due to the reduction of surface nickel oxide species bonded to alumina-zirconia support, in agreement with XRD results (Fig. 2). On the other hand, 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalysts with high strontium loading showed an additional peak at low temperature. 15Ni-8Sr/AZ catalyst showed a major reduction peak at 687°C and a shoulder peak at 584°C. 15Ni-10Sr/AZ showed a major reduction peak at 670°C and another small reduction peak at 491°C. The additional minor reduction band might be attributed to bulk nickel oxide weakly interacted with the support [31,32]. That is, metal-support interaction was weakened and nickel species became more reducible on the catalysts with high promoter loading. Excess amount of strontium species existing on the support may decrease direct interaction between nickel and support, leading to low TPR peak temperature. 3.3 Particle size of reduced catalysts XRD patterns of reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . All the samples exhibited strong diffraction peaks of metallic nickel, and NiO peaks observed for calcined catalysts in Fig. 2 disappeared. From this result, it is inferred that NiO species on the 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts were successfully reduced into metallic nickel during the reduction process (700°C for 2h). In addition, diffraction peaks corresponding to SrNiO3, which were seen in the XRD patterns of calcined 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalysts (Fig. 2), were not detected in the reduced catalysts (Fig. 4). It is believed that SrNiO3 was decomposed during the reduction process along with the reduction of nickel species. Nickel particle size of reduced catalysts was calculated from Ni (2 0 0) diffraction peaks in Fig. 4 using the Scherrer equation, as summarized in Table 2 . It was revealed that nickel particle size showed a volcano-shaped trend with respect to strontium content. Among the samples, un-promoted 15Ni/AZ catalyst showed the largest nickel crystallite size of 10.2nm while 15Ni-6Sr/AZ catalyst exhibited the smallest particle size of 8.2nm. Promotion with strontium on the catalysts affected nickel dispersion, leading to small nickel particle size compared to un-promoted sample. It is expected that decoration of nickel particles by promoter species led to decreased Ni ensemble size and increased dispersion [33]. However, 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalysts exhibited larger Ni particles than 15Ni-6Sr/AZ catalyst. The presence of large nickel particles may be attributed to attenuated metal-support interaction of 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ (Fig. 3). NiO on these samples are apt to go through reduction more easily, leading to enlarged nickel particles during the reduction [34]. TEM images of reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 , along with particle size distributions. 15Ni-6Sr/AZ catalyst (Fig. 5(b)) retained small and uniform nickel particles, while 15Ni/AZ (Fig. 5(a)) and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ (Fig. 5(c)) catalyst showed large nickel crystallites. In detail, 15Ni-6Sr/AZ catalyst exhibited the highest portion of nickel particles with diameter smaller than 10nm. On the other hand, most of nickel particles on the 15Ni/AZ catalyst were larger than 10nm. 3.4 Acidity of the catalysts Fig. 6 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of reduced catalysts. Acidities of the catalysts calculated from TPD peak areas are summarized in Table 3 . It was revealed that addition of strontium promoter decreased acidity of the catalyst, and this effect became more evident with the increase of strontium content. All the catalysts showed a broad desorption band with asymmetric shape, indicating the existence of acidic sites of various strength. Acidity of 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts originates from alumina-zirconia support, where under-coordinated Al3+ species act as acidic sites [35]. On the other hand, alkaline earth metal oxides are known to have various basic sites such as O2− anions and M(alkaline earth metal)-O pairs [36]. Therefore, it is inferred that strontium addition decreased acidity of the catalyst by neutralization of acid sites on alumina-zirconia support. 3.5 Nickel surface area in the reduced catalysts H2-TPD profiles of reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . To quantify the amount of hydrogen desorbed, H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts were deconvoluted into three domains. The first domain with desorption peak temperature lower than 300°C was ascribed to desorbed hydrogen species weakly interacting with active nickel sites. The second domain with desorption peak temperature within the range of 300–600°C was attributed to desorption from strong hydrogen-bonding nickel sites. The last domain with the highest peak temperature (>600°C) was due to hydrogen generated from support and sublayer surface caused by spillover [37,38]. Therefore, the amount of total desorbed hydrogen was calculated from peak areas of the two domains below 600°C. Nickel surface area was determined from the amount of hydrogen uptake by taking into account adsorption stoichiometry and cross-sectional area of nickel atom as described in Section 2. The domain related to hydrogen spillover (>600°C) was excluded in the calculation of nickel surface area. The amount of desorbed hydrogen and the calculated nickel surface area are summarized in Table 4 . Nickel surface area of the catalysts showed a volcano-shaped trend with respect to strontium content, where 15Ni-6Sr/AZ showed the highest nickel surface area of 49.5m2/g-Ni. Nickel surface area increased in the order of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ<15Ni/AZ<15Ni-8Sr/AZ<15Ni-2Sr/AZ<15Ni-4Sr/AZ<15Ni-6Sr/AZ. It should be noted that 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ exhibited lower nickel surface area than 15Ni-6Sr/AZ. This is because excess amount of strontium promoter on the catalyst surface tends to block active sites, leading to decreased area of accessible nickel. Large nickel crystallite size formed during the reduction due to weak metal-support interaction may also be responsible for low nickel surface area of 15Ni-8Sr/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ. Thus, an optimal amount of strontium content was required to obtain the highest nickel surface area of the catalyst. 3.6 Ethanol adsorption capacity of reduced catalysts Extracted EtOH-TPD profiles of reduced 15Ni/AZ (Fig. 8 (a)), 15Ni-6Sr/AZ (Fig. 8(b)), and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ (Fig. 8(c)) catalysts are shown in Fig. 8. EtOH-TPD profiles of the samples were separated into signals for molecularly desorbed ethanol (m/z =31), methane (m/z =16), acetaldehyde (m/z =29), carbon monoxide (m/z =28), and carbon dioxide (m/z =44). These intermediates are known to originate from various reaction pathways during the steam reforming of ethanol [39]. According to previous studies [40,41], adsorption of ethanol on nickel surface during the steam reforming reaction occurs with initial dehydrogenation to form adsorbed ethoxide species (CH3CH2OH→CH3CH2O), followed by CH bond cleavage to yield acetaldehyde species (CH3CH2O →CH3CHO). Among various desorbed carbon-containing intermediates, desorption of molecularly desorbed ethanol and acetaldehyde started to appear at the lowest temperature range (<200°C) for all three samples. This indicates that adsorbed ethanol is initially desorbed back into its molecular form or goes through dehydrogenation to form acetaldehyde. Desorption peaks of methane and carbon oxides then emerged at around 250–300°C. These peaks are expected to originate from decarbonylation of acetaldehyde species previously formed by ethanol dehydrogenation reaction, where CC cleavage occurs to yield carbon oxides along with methyl groups (CH3CHO →CH3CO →CH3 +CO) [42]. Desorption peaks of carbon oxides exhibit much broader profiles, reaching temperature higher than 500°C. Carbon oxides desorbed at relatively low temperature (<300°C) may be attributed to decarbonylation reaction of adsorbed species. On the other hand, carbon oxides desorbed at high temperature may be the result of reaction between oxygen and carbon deposits formed by continuous dehydrogenation of adsorbed methyl groups [43]. The total amount of ethanol originally adsorbed on the catalyst was calculated by summing up the desorbed amount of various carbon-containing intermediates from the respective profiles in Fig. 8. Considering molecularly desorbed ethanol also shows a slight signal at m/z =29, a known portion of original m/z =29 signal was considered as molecularly desorbed ethanol rather than acetaldehyde. The calculated ethanol adsorption capacities of the catalysts are summarized in Table 5 . Ethanol adsorption capacity of the reduced catalysts increased in the order of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ<15Ni/AZ<15Ni-8Sr/AZ<15Ni-2Sr/AZ<15Ni-4Sr/AZ<15Ni-6Sr/AZ, which showed the same trend with nickel surface area calculated from H2-TPD profiles listed in Table 4. The close relationship between nickel surface area and ethanol adsorption capacity implies that ethanol reactant is mainly adsorbed on metallic nickel sites. 3.7 Hydrogen production by steam reforming of ethanol Fig. 9 shows the catalytic performance of 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts in the steam reforming of ethanol at 450°C for a 1000min-reaction. All the catalysts, except for 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ, showed a stable catalytic activity without severe deactivation. Un-promoted 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ with excess amount of promoter exhibited a slight decrease of catalytic activity during the catalytic evaluation. Detailed catalytic performance of 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts after a 1000min-reaction is listed in Table 6 . Ethanol reactants went through complete conversion over all the catalysts. Hydrogen yield showed a volcano-shaped trend with respect to strontium content. Hydrogen yield increased in the order of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ<15Ni/AZ<15Ni-8Sr/AZ<15Ni-2Sr/AZ<15Ni-4Sr/AZ<15Ni-6Sr/AZ. Although addition of strontium as a promoter generally showed a positive effect on hydrogen yield, 15Ni-10Sr/AZ did not show specific improvement of catalytic activity compared to un-promoted 15Ni/AZ. This may be due to insufficient amount of nickel surface area and low ethanol adsorption capacity of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ. The loss of metallic nickel sites of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ not only resulted in low yield but also caused catalyst deactivation. It is interesting to note that 15Ni/AZ showed the highest C2H4 selectivity of 5.6%. This value decreased to 2.4% over 15Ni-2Sr/AZ catalyst. However, the other catalysts with higher strontium content exhibited no selectivity for ethylene. Acid sites on the support are known to be responsible for dehydration of adsorbed ethanol species, which forms ethylene (Eq. (4)) [44]. Neutralization of acid sites induced by introduction of strontium species (Table 3) resulted in decreased amount of ethylene by-product, leading to facilitation of more favorable reaction pathways. The lowest activity of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalyst may be due to its lowest specific surface area (Table 1) and lowest metallic nickel area (Table 4). Considering that dehydrogenation of ethanol is influenced by acid-base pair sites, over-suppression of catalyst acidity in the 15Ni-10Sr/AZ may cause insufficient dehydrogenation reaction, leading to low hydrogen yield [36]. Hydrogen yield of 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts after a 1000min-reaction was plotted against strontium loading and nickel surface area in Fig. 10 . It was revealed that an optimal amount of strontium promoter was required to achieve the best catalytic performance (Fig. 10(a)). A positive correlation between hydrogen yield and nickel surface area was observed as well (Fig. 10(b)), indicating that metallic nickel, which served as an active site, played a crucial role during the ethanol steam reforming reaction. Among the catalysts tested, 15Ni-6Sr/AZ catalyst with the highest nickel surface area and the largest ethanol adsorption capacity showed the best catalytic performance. 3.8 Characterization of used catalysts Fig. 11 shows the XRD patterns of 15Ni/AZ and 15Ni-XSr/AZ catalysts after a 1000min-reaction. All the catalysts exhibited a strong diffraction peak indicative of carbon, due to coke formation during the reaction. XRD peaks corresponding to metallic nickel phase were also observed as in the case of reduced samples (Fig. 4). However, intensity of XRD peak indicating metallic nickel was attenuated in all the samples, because substantial amount of coke on the used catalysts induced the dilution effect [24]. Nickel crystallite size of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ calculated by applying the Scherrer equation on Ni (1 1 1) peak was 10.7nm (Nickel crystallite size of reduced 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalyst was 9.5nm). The increase of nickel crystallite size after the reaction is expected to originate from metal sintering, because 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalyst showed the weakest metal-support interaction (Fig. 3). TEM images of 15Ni/AZ, 15Ni-6Sr/AZ, and 15Ni-10Sr/AZ catalysts after a 1000min-reaction are shown in Fig. 12 . The presence of filamentous carbon was observed in all the catalysts. 4 Conclusions A series of strontium-promoted nickel catalysts supported on alumina-zirconia xerogel (15Ni-XSr/AZ) were prepared for ethanol steam reforming reaction. For comparison, un-promoted nickel catalyst (15Ni/AZ) was also prepared. The effect of Sr content on the characteristics and catalytic activities was investigated. All the calcined catalysts showed a mesoporous structure, while surface area decreased with increasing strontium content due to pore blockage. Supported nickel existed in the form of nickel oxide on the calcined catalysts. An appropriate amount of strontium promotion reduced nickel crystalline size. Hydrogen yield of the catalysts after a 1000min-reaction showed a volcano-shaped trend with respect to strontium content. Catalytic performance was enhanced with promotion of strontium up to 6wt%, because nickel surface area was increased due to high nickel dispersion and because formation of ethylene by-product was suppressed due to support modification. The catalyst containing excess amount of strontium promoter was not effective for hydrogen production, because strontium severely covered catalyst surface. Hydrogen yield increased in the order of 15Ni-10Sr/AZ<15Ni/AZ<15Ni-8Sr/AZ<15Ni-2Sr/AZ<15Ni-4Sr/AZ<15Ni-6Sr/AZ. Correlation between catalytic activity and nickel surface area revealed that the trend of these two factors was well matched, indicating that nickel sites were deeply involved in the ethanol steam reforming process. It was concluded that an optimal amount of strontium promoter was required for efficient hydrogen yield. Among the catalysts tested, 15Ni-6Sr/AZ with the highest nickel surface area and the largest ethanol adsorption capacity showed the highest hydrogen yield. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 (15Ni-XSr/AZ) xerogel catalysts with different strontium content (X, wt%) were prepared by an epoxide-driven sol-gel method followed by a co-impregnation method. Un-promoted Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 (15Ni/AZ) xerogel catalyst was also prepared according to the similar methods for comparison. Surface area of the catalysts decreased with increasing strontium content. Excess amount of impregnated strontium on the catalyst led to weakened metal-support interaction, inducing formation of large nickel particles in the reduced catalysts with high Sr loading. Introduction of strontium promoter reduced acidity of the catalysts, leading to a more favorable reaction pathway during the ethanol steam reforming reaction. Promotion with strontium generally had a positive effect on the catalytic activity due to enhanced nickel dispersion and suppressed acidity. Nickel surface area and ethanol adsorption capacity exhibited volcano-shaped trends with respect to strontium content. Hydrogen yield increased with increasing nickel surface area and with increasing ethanol adsorption capacity of the catalyst. Among the catalysts tested, 15Ni-6Sr/AZ, which retained the highest nickel surface area and the largest ethanol adsorption capacity, showed the highest hydrogen yield in the steam reforming of ethanol. It was concluded that an optimal amount of strontium promoter was required to achieve the best catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Sr content on hydrogen production by steam reforming of ethanol over Ni-Sr/Al2O3-ZrO2 xerogel catalysts
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
